did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Afrika Bambaataa hip hop archive, circa 1972-2016.
did.physdesc: Vinyl records and other A/V Recordings, Financial Records, Manuscripts, Memorabilia, Photocopies, Photographs, Printed Materials, Publications.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Approximately 40,000 sound recordings representing Bambaataa's music collection from the 1970s to the present. The archive also includes books, documents, and files relating to the founding and spread of the Universal Zulu Nation; and videos, papers, and clothing.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Afrika Bambaataa is an American disc jockey, singer, and songwriter from the South Bronx, New York. Often called the “Godfather” of Hip Hop, Bambaataa has helped to define Hip Hop since it emerged in the South Bronx in the 1970s. One of a handful of Hip Hop's 1970s originators, Bambaataa gave Hip Hop its name, and was the first to define its core artistic elements - DJing, rapping, break dancing, and graffiti art - under one cultural umbrella. His cultural organization, the Universal Zulu Nation, has helped to spread Hip Hop culture throughout the world. His genre-defining 1982 song "Planet Rock" and subsequent electro-funk tracks have become icons of hip-hop and electronic music. In 2007 he was nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Approximately 40,000 sound recordings representing Bambaataa's music collection from the 1970s to the present. The archive also includes books, documents, and files relating to the founding and spread of the Universal Zulu Nation; and videos, papers, and clothing.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Access to collection restricted until completion of processing, with the exception of vinyl records that have been individually cataloged.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p:
Vinyl that has been cataloged can be viewed but not played. Due to the fragility and potential degradation of moving image and sound recordings, viewing and listening is limited to items that have been digitized. If an item is in another media format, you may request to have the item digitized for access. Information on ordering access copies may be found on the Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections webpage.
Audio visual media that has been digitized: SR-6803, SR-6889, SR-8036, SR-8807, SR-8808, SR-8810 to SR-8816, SR-8818 to SR-8825, SR-10341 to SR-10370.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Afrika Bambaataa Hip Hop Archive, #8094. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

did.unittitle: Series IX. Music collection
Acetate discs/Lacquer discs

scopecontent.p: The rarest items in this series are in boxes 104 and 105. All 10 inch discs are in box 104. Box 103 contains the less rare items that were not digitized.

arrangement.p: Removed from original jackets and resleeved in buffered sleeves. If original jacket had post-it note from Renegades of Rhythm tour, the post-it was kept on the jacket. Original jackets are stored behind acetate disc.

processinfo.p: Subseries contains discs made of lacquer on aluminum often referred to as "Acetates". These are some of the rarest items in the Bambaataa collection and are very fragile. Jackets and discs have often been stored separately because of their fragility. Included are several mixes of beats and samples, some produced by the Sunshine Sound record label and many others with no credits. It is possible that Bambaataa had them pressed for his own use, but we are unable to determine based on the descriptive information written or printed on the jackets or labels. This series also contains master pressings of some of Bambaataa’s albums and singles and those of other artists. Many of the items in Box 104 and 105 have been digitized. There are a few vinyl discs in the series that were misfiled. Titles have been taken from the label on on the vinyl or what is written on the jacket, unless, once digitized, its found innacurate. This will be indicated in the scope and contents note for that item. Side one and side two are sometimes on two different discs because the acetates were used for pressing vinyl.

did.unittitle: Meireles E Sua Orquestra - B-2

processinfo.p: Label obscured. According to Discogs may also contain Axis' "Ela Ela". Post it note from Renegades of Rhythm tour "Acetate (presumabely pressed up for Bam exclusively at his request) of Carnival, Batucada stuff."

did.unittitle: Baby Huey - Listen to me

processinfo.p: Label obscured.

userestrict.p: Came in second accession. Consider digitizing audio.

did.unittitle: Hubbard, Freddie - In the pocket
Bloodstone - Do you wanna do a thing
Moody, James - This masquerade

userestrict.p: HANDLE WITH CARE. Lacquer cracking and popping off. In special enclosure in box 106.

did.unittitle: Afrika Bambaataa - Jungle rock (mix by Bambaataa)

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Mix of beats and samples, drums, funk, disco.

did.unittitle: Munich Machine - Get on the funk train (Canadian mix by J.L.)

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Remix of song.

did.unittitle: MacDonald, Ralph - Jam on the groove

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Song sampled and remixed

did.unittitle: Bobo Drake - Jungle

processinfo.p: Label obscured and "Scratch" written on it. Disco mix includes Love Unlimited Orchestra's "Brazilian love song", Jimmy 'Bo' Horne's "Gimme some", Jermaine Jackson's "Erucu" and more. Mixed by Robert Drake according to Discogs.

did.unittitle: Negron, Jay - Hollywood

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Disco mix featuring Village People's "San Francisco" and "In Hollywood (Everybody is a star)", Label has artist as "Jay" Jay Negron according to Discogs.

did.unittitle: Rare Earth - Happy song

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Disco mix of Rare Earth's "Happy song". Discogs.com credits remix to François Kevorkian.

did.unittitle: Salsoul Orchestra - Magic bird of fire

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Found via Shazam and Discogs.

did.unittitle: Salsoul Orchestra - Magic bird of fire

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Found via Shazam and Discogs.

did.unittitle: Unknown artist - Loose hips ; Rump bump

processinfo.p: Renegades of Rhythm note on sleeve "78 novelty pop, x, politically incorrect Asian impersonation (e)"

did.unittitle: Ramses II - Osiris

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Mix of different disco songs and beats

did.unittitle: Kevorkian, François - Groove city

processinfo.p: Label obscured. Mix of various disco, soul, and drums music including Michael Zager Band "Let's all chant". Remix by Francois Kevorkian taken from Discogs, not indicated on the disc.

did.unittitle: Chic - Good times

processinfo.p: Remix of Chic's "Good times" with conga beat.

did.unittitle: Jimmy[?] - Disco party ; Space funk

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "D.J. Afrika Bambaataa: Special Funk Music, Funk Jam Pt. 2". This is a disco mix featuring The Trammps "Disco party", Bruce Johnston's "Pipeline", Blackbyrds "Rock Creek Park", Peter Brown's "Do you wanna get funky with me", Jimmy Castor Bunch's "L.T.D." and more.

did.unittitle: Clark, Joseph - Disco boogie

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "D.J. Afrika Bambaataa: Special Funk Disco Music, Disco Boogie by Joseph." Instrumental disco mix.

did.unittitle: Jimmy [?] - Zulu funk

processinfo.p: Record label obscured and "Bambaataa" written on label. Samples of disco and funk music. Renegades of Rhythm post it "Cool breaks mix".

did.unittitle: Jimmy Jim - Funk jam pt. 2

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "Jacket: D.J. Afrika Bambaataa Special funk records: 1. Disco Party (Mix by Jimmy Jim), 2. Space Funk (by Manzell)". Disco and funk beats and samples.

did.unittitle: Unknown artist - Zulu madness

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "D.J. Afrika Bambaataa Special Rockin Music: "Zulu Madness". Unclear who created the mix, possibly Bambaataa. Renegades of Rhythm post it: "Funk & disco breaks"

did.unittitle: Afrika Bambaataa - Bambaata[sic] beats ; Frank Sinatra, standards, showtunes

arrangement.p: ***Has catalog record, no need to include in finding aid?*** Moved from Renegades of Rhythm box 5 to Acetates for digitization

processinfo.p: Side 1:Mix of beats and samples, drums, funk, disco, horns; Side 2: Frank Sinatra and other standards and showtunes. Two-sided acetate so possibly made later. Part of the Renegades of Rhythm tour.

did.unittitle: Unknown artist - Groove beat

processinfo.p: Side one: Beats, loops, including Sample of Sly & The Family Stone "Thank you (falettinme be mice elf again)" and others; Side two: German music, Indian music? Samples

did.unittitle: Unknown artist - Sophisticated funk

processinfo.p: Mix of songs, beats by artists unknown. Renegades of Rhythm post it: "2 break edits I don't recognize…"

did.unittitle: Spyder D - Rapple (Big apple rappin)(inst.)
X.D. Prod. - NJRC disco brakes

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "D.J. Afrika Special: Brake[sic] music, Zulu Nation". Disco breaks and beats.

did.unittitle: Jimmy Jim - Zulu rainin' hell

processinfo.p: Record label obscured. Written on jacket "D.J. Afrika Bambaataa Special funk Break disco: Zulu Rainin' Hell, Mix by Jimmy Jim". Renegades of Rhythm post it "Known funk breaks, Jimmy Castor, etc."

did.unittitle: Cotton Candy - Havin' fun
Afrika Bambaataa & the Soulsonic Force - Electric boogieland ; Don't you ever forget pt 2 (Shinning stars)[sic]

processinfo.p: Electric Boogieland sounds like an early demo of Planet Rock without lyrics. Post-it note from Renegades of Rhythm "TRANSFER-Early demo of Planet Rock, backed with unreleased D.S.T. & Infinity 4 track-TRANSFER"
